lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can read a short text about a vegetable orchestra and find key details such as instruments and foods.
supportStrategies: (Reading) Read the text aloud. Ask: “What do they use as instruments?” Students underline “cucumber trumpet,” etc., in the SB.
stretchStrategies: Create a word sorting activity with real and nonsense words containing a_e and i_e (e.g., “cake,” “blape,” “kite,” “snite”). Students sort the words and then try to use the real ones in creative sentences related to Unit vocabulary.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can trace and write the phonics patterns “a_e” and “i_e” to form simple words.
supportStrategies: (Phonics) Say and write a_e, i_e words: “cake,” “bike.” Students repeat, trace, and draw a line from word to picture.
stretchStrategies: Create a word sorting activity with real and nonsense words containing a_e and i_e (e.g., “cake,” “blape,” “kite,” “snite”). Students sort the words and then try to use the real ones in creative sentences related to Unit vocabulary.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can explain how vegetables can be used as musical instruments.
supportStrategies: (Music) Show real/imagined vegetable instruments from the text. Ask: “Could we play a carrot flute?” Students discuss with yes/no and “why/why not?”

items: Bạn có thích ăn bánh mì không? >> you like eat bread? [do you like to eat bánh mì?]
Con không thích >> I no/not like [I don't like]
Playground words tend to be long and phonetically difficult (slide, see-saw, swings, climbing frame)
Some sports not well known in VN (baseball, cricket, rugby, paragliding, water skiing)
A wide variety of syllabus hobbies may be less popular or available to some Vietnamese students (practising the flute; seeing famous paintings), although many overlap

Unstressed vowels do not really exist in Vietnamese, so these need extra practice. Make sure the final vowel of computer is a light schwa, not a heavy com-pu-TER. Same with the final vowel of banana. Or the second syllable of elephant. And so on.
Bạn muốn ăn gì? >> you want to eat what? [what do you want to eat?]
This is extremely difficult to master, especially combined with do-support.
